newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: INTERVIEW-Lithuanian minister hails new loan deal.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Lithuanian minister hails new loan deal.

text.p: Lithuanian Finance Minister Algimantas Krizhinauskas said on Monday a new syndicated loan the Baltic state is to sign was proof of investor confidence.
Lithuania is tomorrow to sign a deal with J.P. Morgan for a synidicated loan worth $75 million, priced at 2.25 basis points over LIBOR with a maturity of one year and one day.
"This loan is a strong sign of confidence in our economy," Krizhinauskas told Reuters.
"It was negotiated before we received our credit rating and we still managed to get very favourable terms," he added.

Lithuania was this month given a credit rating by Moody's, the first for a former Soviet state, and intends to get ratings from other international agencies. It got a Ba2 for foreign currency debt and Ba3 for bank deposits.
Tommorow's signing comes after the country in April arranged a $33 million syndicated loan via J.P. Morgan, that was priced at 2.50 bp over Libor.
Lithuania has several times tapped the international markets, seeking to cover its 700 million litas budget deficit.
Its debt has received a fairly good reception, although it has been dubbed the slowest reformer of the three Baltic states and was hit by a banking crisis last year.
Krizhinauskas, whose Lithuanian Democratic Labour Party (LDLP) is facing defeat at forthcoming elections, said the aim of the loans was to reduce domestic borrowing costs.
"The fall in domestic yields will benefit the business sector, because it will force our commercial banks to extend more credits to companies," he said.
"They cannot make all of their profit from the local T-bill market any more," he added.
T-bill rates soared after the banking crisis but now range between nine and 12 percent.
Krizhinauskas said all of the deficit was now covered.
"This government has not made any populist increases in public sector wages and salaries and so both the budget deficit and inflation have been kept down," he said.
Lithuania did not suffer from inflation in August for the first time since it regained independence from the former Soviet Union in 1991. The year-on-year rate was 24.3 percent.
